0.text:
Hello everybody, Claudia Boleyn here and today
I'm reviewing Death In Heaven which is the

4.text:
series finale of Series Eight Doctor Who,
this episode was written by Steven Moffat.

9.text:
Okay, so I wanted to start this review in
the same way that the episode started, by

14.text:
talking about Clara Who, which is Clara as
the Doctor. In the trailer for this episode

20.text:
I think a lot of people were quite worried
by the fact that Clara said that Clara Oswald

25.text:
never existed, because a lot of her early
story arc was about Clara being The Impossible

32.text:
Girl and she wasn't a normal, ordinary human,
no, she was scattered through time and the

38.text:
Doctor only picked her up to investigate her,
and she became a bit, in my opinion she became

44.text:
a little bit treated like an object instead
of a person in many ways, she was a problem

50.text:
to be solved instead of a person and so we
didn't get that much characterisation, so

54.text:
it was a little bit worrying to see that that
in the trailer but I didn't judge by the trailer

58.text:
because I never judge ahead of time, I always
wait until I've seen something to see if it's

62.text:
okay or not, and I actually thought it was
really good. I thought it was a really clever

67.text:
tactic coming from Clara because we know Clara's
a smart young woman, and I think a lot of

72.text:
us might have considered that before. It's
a really cool idea to pretend to be the Doctor,

77.text:
especially with Missy being around, which
is a female incarnation of the Master. I just

82.text:
thought it was really cool and clever and
it did actually save her life, so good thinking,

86.text:
Clara.
I also loved how in the title sequence we

89.text:
had Jenna Coleman's name first and we also
had Jenna Coleman's eyes appearing in the

94.text:
galaxy or whatever that was showing. I thought
that was really cool.

98.text:
Okay so my favourite character in the episode
was Missy. I am a massive, massive fan of

104.text:
the Master, like you would not believe. Not
as a person, not as a person, the Master does

110.text:
some terrible things, Missy does some terrible
things, but as a character I find him and

115.text:
her to be extremely compelling to watch. I
was watching Logopolis the other day, which

122.text:
was obviously, it's the Fourth Doctor's regeneration
story. I'm sure you've already seen it. If

127.text:
you haven't then watch it. And it has Anthony
Ainley's Master in it, and it's absolutely

133.text:
hilarious. I just wanted to point out, I'm
gonna get to this later in my review, in fact,

137.text:
no, I'll talk about it now. There was a kiss
in this episode between the Doctor and Missy

142.text:
and I actually really liked it because it
wasn't like a… a… romantic-sexualised

148.text:
kiss, it was the sort of thing the Doctor
would do, it was an affectionate kind of kiss…

154.text:
a gesture similar to, I thought, when John's
Simm's Master and David Tennant's Doctor had

161.text:
their heads together in Last of the Time Lords-
No! It's not the Last of the Time Lords, it

166.text:
was The End of Time Part One. Yeah, I think
that's the one. Yeah, I just really loved

171.text:
that it was a really tender, emotional sort
of moment. The reason I'm bringing this up

176.text:
with regard to Logopolis which is, as indicated
by my screenshot which I'm gonna try and put

181.text:
on the screen… now… maybe here, I don't
know if that will work or not. It's not the

185.text:
first kiss the Doctor and the Master have
had. I'm sure they had a sneaky little kiss

189.text:
in Logopolis. Maybe you can't see it properly
from the thing I've put on the screen but

194.text:
if you watch the episode it is actually quite
funny because it does look like they actually

197.text:
kiss. And in my headcanon, they totally, they
totally did kiss at that point.

202.text:
Obviously there are issues with heteronormativity.
I spoke about that in my last video review,

208.text:
in which, as a queer woman it was a bit of
a kick in the teeth that the first time we

211.text:
see any sort of romantic gesture between the
Doctor and the Master, like an explicit…

218.text:
when I say explicit, I don't mean like triple
X explicit, I just mean that like… canonical,

223.text:
is what I'm trying to say, I shouldn't have
said explicit. But the only time we get some

227.text:
sort of canonical sort of romantic gesture
like the kiss, it's when we have a Time Lady

234.text:
Master and a Time Lord Doctor, and it is a
bit of a kick in the teeth. But I did like

238.text:
the kiss and again, I didn't think Missy was
sexualised in this episode. A lot of people

244.text:
worried about that and I talked about that
in my last review as well, but I really don't

248.text:
think she was sexualised. I thought she was
written as pure Master, I thought pretty much

253.text:
all her lines were dead on. I could easily
imagine… there's so much pantomime-y Anthony

260.text:
Ainley going on with her this episode and
a lot of John Simm as well. Also… the only

266.text:
thing I did think about Missy, the only thing
I didn't quite get, is the fact that she had

272.text:
an army of Cybermen that she'd been working
on for a very long time, and then she just

277.text:
gave them to the Doctor for a birthday present.
Now some people have pointed out that this

282.text:
might be because… Steven Moffat's women
do have a tendency of doing a lot of things

288.text:
for the male characters, as is in their lives
revolve around them suddenly, and it does

292.text:
seem a little bit odd that the Master has
no plan of her own, she has… what was the

298.text:
Master gonna do with a Cyberman army anyway,
eh? What's she gonna want with that? And then

302.text:
she… it just did kind of strike me as odd
that she just gave the army over to the Doctor.

308.text:
But in Steven Moffat's defence here, I can
kind of see how this would work as well because

313.text:
it's a mind game and it is true that the Master
is trying to make a point that the Doctor

320.text:
is quite similar to her, or to him, and I
do kind of get it as well. I mean I just think

327.text:
this episode should have been a three parter
to be honest. I just don't think there was

331.text:
enough time to get into all the characters,
cause when you have a character like the Master

335.text:
or like Missy, you just want to delve into
them and their motives and… I don't know.

341.text:
For me personally it felt like a little bit
of a cop out that the climax of her massive

347.text:
plan was to give the Doctor his own army.
I don't know. I loved the shot when she appeared

354.text:
from the air like an evil Mary Poppins. I
think that's great. And I think, I also like

358.text:
to think that she's done that deliberately.
She's styled herself like a bad Mary Poppins

361.text:
because we know that the Master has a liking
for Earth tv, and Earth film, so I'm sure

366.text:
that's a reference from the Master. Michelle
Gomez is absolutely amazing. I have nothing

371.text:
else to say about Michelle Gomez's portrayal
of the Master other than that it's perfection

377.text:
and she just, she just fits the lineup of
Masters so well. I can see her with Roger

384.text:
Delgado and Anthony Ainley and John Simm and
the lot of them, I think she's amazing and

389.text:
I think she's so worthy of that part and I
am happy, I'm so happy that we've got a lady

396.text:
Master. I'm extremely happy that I can refer
to the Master as she. It's just wonderful

400.text:
and I feel like it really opens the door to
the idea of having a Time Lady Doctor at some

405.text:
point. I really do feel like this is a progressive
step forwards and I love it!

411.text:
Okay so another point that a lot of people
brought up was the Brigadier, so as we know

416.text:
the Brigadier was, well we first saw the Brigadier
in portrait form on the plane which was emotional

422.text:
and I'm attached to the Brigadier, I'm a fan
of Classic Who, and I really really like the

429.text:
Brigadier and the death of Nicholas Courtney
was, you know, it's really sad because he

434.text:
made such a great contribution to Doctor Who
and his character's always gonna live on in

440.text:
the fandom, always. The Brigadier is such
a loved, a beloved character and rightly so,

445.text:
so it was nice to see his portrait. The thing
that people didn't like, or that people debated

450.text:
over, wasn't the fact that he was remembered
and that he was in the episode, it was the

454.text:
fact that it's heavily heavily implied that
he became a Cyberman and then caught Kate

463.text:
Stewart as she fell out of a plane and then
disappeared off into the sky at the end of

467.text:
the episode after a heartwarming salute from
the Doctor.

470.text:
I don't know what to think about this because
I actually think it's kind of nice that we've

475.text:
still got the Brigadier around and that he's
still protecting the Earth in some way and

480.text:
that he's still looking out for the Doctor,
and the fact that he caught his daughter,

485.text:
that gave me tears in my eyes. I just find
that incredibly emotional. It's like in Doomsday

492.text:
when Pete caught Rose, that's one of my favourite
Doctor Who moments of all time, throughout

497.text:
all Doctor Who and I wish we'd seen the Brigadier
catch Kate because… although I would have

503.text:
been a crying wreck and I wouldn't have been
able to watch the episode properly, but that

507.text:
idea is beautiful, I really do like that.
I think it's very touching.

510.text:
The only issue is that, is the Brigadier now,
like, all sort of mangled within the Cyberman

515.text:
suit with his face all sort of like drilled
and changed and is he living in agony? I don't

522.text:
really want to think of the Brigadier living
like that and it is kind of sad. I'm glad

527.text:
we never had to open the helmet on the Brigadier
because it would have disturbed a lot of people,

530.text:
I think. And I think then the idea wouldn't
have been quite so romantic and exciting,

535.text:
it would have just been scary and horrific.
I'm on the fence about that so I'd be interested

539.text:
to know what you think about that, cause there
are some strong opinions going around about

543.text:
this, cause people feel passionately about
the Brigadier, you know, rightly so, the Brigadier's

547.text:
a loved character, so tell me what you thought
about that and I'd be really interested to

551.text:
see which way it kind of sways in the comment
section.

553.text:
Right, now unfortunately I have to get a little
bit political again and I know I do this in

558.text:
my reviews quite a lot and a lot of people
say 'keep the politics out of the reviews'

561.text:
but I have to get this in here. Right, there
are a lot of people, there are quite a lot

565.text:
of people online right now hating on Danny.
Now they really hate Danny. But for weird

570.text:
reasons. Like I can understand disliking a
character for things their character does

576.text:
which are bad, like I can understand people
thinking 'oh, I didn't really like the way

581.text:
in which Danny was acting a bit controlling
towards Clara'. Now that's a valid criticism,

586.text:
although, you know, it's a debatable point
whether he was being controlling or not, but

591.text:
that's still a valid criticism and an opinion
some people have. But it does worry me when

595.text:
people bring out the weirdest things against
Danny, and then act like he's the worst character

600.text:
in the world ever, and surprisingly enough
this also happened with Martha Jones, and

605.text:
still happens with Martha Jones quite a lot,
and this actually happens to people of colour

609.text:
in fandom often, and it is a little bit worrying.
I mean the hatred towards Martha Jones on

616.text:
tumblr sometimes is very extreme and worrying
because there's no real reason to hate Martha

620.text:
Jones. Like if you dislike her as a character,
that's fine, that's absolutely fine, no-one's

625.text:
trying to police your opinions, but when you're
pulling out all these weird descriptions of

629.text:
her and, you know, 'oh, she was the most terrible
person ever and I hate her and she was boring

635.text:
and she did nothing and she was ugly' and
then it just starts, you start to think, you're

640.text:
starting to sound a little bit racist really,
because that thing that you hate that she

644.text:
just did, Rose also did that, but you like
Rose a lot. So anyway, I'm getting away from

648.text:
the point here, although it is still part
of what I'm talking about. So this whole Danny

652.text:
thing, a lot of people have decided they hate
him because he is, apparently selfish in this

657.text:
episode. They think he's selfish for wanting
to become a Cyberman, as in wanting to have

661.text:
his emotions turned off, and they also think
he was selfish for sending that little boy

667.text:
through the portal or whatever, instead of
himself to come back to Clara.

671.text:
I have to respectfully but very forcefully
disagree with this description of Danny. I

676.text:
do not think Danny, in this episode, is selfish
in the slightest. Now I had an ask the other

682.text:
day about this and it suddenly hit me why
this means so much to me, and it's because,

690.text:
I suppose it's a bit of an analogy, it could,
it can be if you look into it, an analogy

695.text:
for mental illness or suicide, you know, euthanasia,
it could be an analogy for that. And the fact

700.text:
that Danny's getting called selfish and this
horrible man that people hate because he was

707.text:
in so much pain that he wanted someone to
help him end it, is kind of disturbing to

712.text:
me. But I mean, poor Danny, Danny was in actual
complete mental and physical pain. We know

719.text:
from The Age of Steel that if Cybermen have
their human consciousness in them, we know

724.text:
that destroys them, that's a destroying thing
for a human to see, I mean those Cybermen

728.text:
were blowing up with it, and also poor Danny,
his poor face it looked so painful, I mean

733.text:
he must have been in absolute agony. I just
don't understand how people could call him

737.text:
selfish for that. He couldn't have done it
himself. He's got big Cyberman hands and he

741.text:
can't see into his chest thingy. I just, I
don't get that. I know it's a bit odd that

746.text:
he put Clara in the graveyard full of Cybermen,
but I think, I don't actually think that's

751.text:
anything to do with Danny, I think that's
just a case of Steven Moffat wanting to get

754.text:
all his characters into the same setting for
the end of, for the climax of the episode.

759.text:
I don't think that's actually Danny's intention.
I don't think he deliberately took her to

761.text:
that graveyard.
There was that moment where he raised his

764.text:
arm at her a little bit. That was a bit odd.
It was a tiny bit odd, like he was about to

768.text:
shoot her because she had declared that she
loved the Doctor the most out of everybody,

774.text:
but again, that could just be his Cyber-ness,
his Cyber-conciousness coming through, or

779.text:
it could have been a lapse in the writing,
but anyway. Now as for the child coming through

783.text:
the portal instead of himself, I don't think
that's selfish at all, I think that's selfless.

787.text:
Now what Danny did to that child is terrible,
accident or not, you know, he did, he killed

793.text:
a civilian child, which is an awful thing.
But he's done literally everything in his

798.text:
power to somehow atone for this. I mean, he's
even given his one option to come back to

806.text:
Clara to live his life, to this little boy.
That's not selfish, that's selfless. And yes,

813.text:
I know it's a bit much for Clara to suddenly
have some child walking into her apartment

818.text:
and being told she has to find his parents,
but I mean, there's not much Danny can do

822.text:
about that, and I actually admire him for
that decision. I don't think that's a selfish

825.text:
decision whatsoever. Now a lot of people think
that Clara's actually pregnant, so I think

830.text:
that's why they're so, you know, up in arms
about this, because, you know, poor Clara's

833.text:
gonna probably be a single mum, if she is
pregnant. People think this because of Orson

838.text:
Pink, who we saw earlier this series, and
also because on the post-it notes at the beginning

843.text:
of last episode, people have noticed, eagle-eyed
viewers have noticed, that there was one that

847.text:
said 'three months' indicating that perhaps
she's three months pregnant. And also the

851.text:
Doctor told Clara that she was a mess of chemicals
at the moment, so I think it does point towards

856.text:
the idea that she's pregnant, and it's ever
so sad for her, but that's not Danny's fault

860.text:
and I don't think he's selfish at all.
Now I have to talk about Osgood, lovely Osgood,

866.text:
I can't believe she's dead, that was devastating
to me because I love her. She, for me, represents

871.text:
fangirls. I think that's sort of her point.
She represents those of us that love Doctor

876.text:
Who, those women that are a bit nerdy and
kinda love it, and are a bit obsessed with

881.text:
the Doctor, the sort of women that cosplay
and wear bow ties and wear scarves, long Tom

886.text:
Baker scarves. I just loved her and the fact
she died upset me a lot. It reminded me a

892.text:
little bit of when Lynda with a Y died in
The Parting of the Ways, because I was convinced

898.text:
Osgood was going to be a companion and I was
actually excited about that. I had that little

902.text:
hope in my heart that Osgood was going to
be the next companion and I was so excited,

907.text:
and then she got killed by Missy.
It was upsetting to me, seeing that lovely

913.text:
Victorian-style boot of Missy's crushing Osgood's
glasses. It was symbolic of us fangirls getting

921.text:
stamped into the dust, which could well be
an analogy of the last series of Doctor Who

928.text:
and our hopes for it, but never mind because
this series has been a big improvement on

933.text:
that, and you know I'm not a big fan of Steven
Moffat's writing, but I do think he's done

938.text:
a good job here, so I won't complain too much.
The scene with the Doctor looking for Gallifrey

943.text:
after typing in the coordinates Missy gave
him and then opening the door and not seeing

948.text:
Gallifrey was, I actually think that was my
favourite scene of the episode. The music

954.text:
that played in this scene made it. I cannot
praise Murray Gold enough for his music. I

959.text:
just think that Doctor Who would not be the
same without Murray Gold and I will be devastated

964.text:
when he leaves. He captures exactly the right
feeling for every scene he writes for. I just,

971.text:
I don't know how he does it and I think the
man is an absolute musical genius and he does

974.text:
not get nearly enough recognition for what
he does, because he is, he's right up there

982.text:
with the best composers in my opinion, I just
think he's fantastic.

986.text:
I like to think that Missy has just, after
being 'shot' by the Brigadier in Cyberman

992.text:
garb, I like to think that she just got a
little bit pissed off and just moved Gallifrey

996.text:
ever so slightly to one side, just to annoy
the Doctor. I like to think Gallifrey was

1001.text:
there, Gallifrey was just maybe behind the
TARDIS or something like that. She just…

1005.text:
and she was watching. She was watching the
whole time. I have this theory/headcanon/wishful

1010.text:
thinking thing going on, in which Missy is
actually now the President of Gallifrey. She's

1016.text:
disposed of Rassilon, Rassilon's gone now,
Rassilon's bad, Rassilon's gone. I like to

1021.text:
think that she's got Romana hostage and we're
going to get Romana soon. In my headcanon

1026.text:
this is what's going on. Romana is her leverage
with the Doctor, to get the Doctor back. I

1031.text:
think that she wants the Doctor to come back
to Gallifrey and rule with her. I have said

1037.text:
it before but I do think there is something
amazing between the Doctor and the Master,

1041.text:
and I think it's a mixture of, it's kind of
romantic, but at the same time it's friendship,

1046.text:
and they're enemies, but they love each other
in this weird way, and I love complex relationships

1052.text:
like that and it just, I'm so excited even
talking about it, seeing those two characters

1057.text:
on screen together, every word they exchange
is just exciting and thrilling to me cause

1065.text:
they're iconic characters, the Doctor and
Master are two of my favourite fictional characters

1068.text:
ever and I cannot get enough of them.
The line where Missy seemed to be telling

1074.text:
the truth actually, at this point, and really
being quite honest about herself, was when

1078.text:
she just said to the Doctor, I just want my
friend back, and that kind of killed me, that

1083.text:
really did. And also when the Doctor was talking
about how he had a friend and they ran together,

1089.text:
and he thought that they were the same, but
when they were older they found out that they

1092.text:
weren't, and this imagery that Missy's trying
to destroy the world and he's desperate to

1099.text:
put it back together, but he can't do it in
time and he's scrambling to do it, and it

1104.text:
was delicious writing, like for me it was
just amazing. And I'm so happy that Steven

1110.text:
Moffat has done that because I always worry,
I mean, I worried when we had John Simm's

1116.text:
Master, I worried about whether it would be
Master-y enough and if it would work, if the

1121.text:
dynamic between the Doctor and the Master
would work, and it did, and Missy and Twelve

1125.text:
work perfectly, as well, and I… hats off
to Steven Moffat for that, cause I can't imagine

1131.text:
it's easy to write a Doctor and a Master that
have that much chemistry, such a compelling

1137.text:
atmosphere around them when they're in the
same scene, so you know, I think that's impressive.

1142.text:
Something I was asked to mention in this review,
and I completely agree with it as well but

1146.text:
I wasn't sure where to put it in this review
so I thought I'd bang it on the end, is that

1150.text:
there is a tendency of the people of colour
in Doctor Who to get killed off. Now I know

1156.text:
that Danny had a story arc and he was a main
character in this. I'm not actually happy

1162.text:
with the way his story arc went, I think he
did deserve better, to be perfectly honest.

1167.text:
Although his story arc was exciting, he did
become a sort of, he became the solution to

1172.text:
the problem rather than a real person with
real feelings and a real emotional connection

1176.text:
that we could kind of feel for. So yeah there
is a tendency for the people of colour in

1184.text:
Doctor Who to get killed off. I did notice
we had Sanjeev Bhaskar in this episode playing

1190.text:
Colonel… do you know what, I can't remember
what his second name was, and he got kind

1194.text:
of flung out of, sucked out of the window
by a Cyberman, which was interesting to say

1201.text:
the least. But anyway, I was just asked to
bring this up and I did want to draw attention

1205.text:
to the fact that there is this odd strange
sort of racist school of thought bubbling

1211.text:
under the Doctor Who fandom at the moment,
which is kind of worrying. And like I said

1218.text:
it's fine to dislike a character of colour.
It's fine. But you've gotta have a reason

1223.text:
to dislike them because when you don't have
a reason to dislike them, or you like the

1227.text:
white characters for the same reason you dislike
the characters of colour, then it does come

1233.text:
across as slightly racist, so just bear that
in mind, and if I were you I'd look out for

1238.text:
that if I were you. Like I said before, it's
quite interesting to play spot the racist

1242.text:
that doesn't want to be spotted as a racist
when you're on Doctor Who forums.

1245.text:
I hope you can still hear me because it's
raining outside right now and I'm in the conservatory

1249.text:
so it's making quite a lot of noise out there.
But I just wanted to say thank you so much

1252.text:
for watching my reviews, if you have watched
my reviews. This might be the first one you've

1256.text:
watched and you might have hated it, and you
might have thought to yourself, well that's

1259.text:
twenty minutes of my life I'm never gonna
get back, in which case I genuinely apologise

1264.text:
for that, but I hope you appreciated some
of what I've said, and maybe you just appreciated

1269.text:
my brother's Lego death star, which is very
impressive. It's not mine, I get loads of

1272.text:
asks about that. It's not mine, it's my brother's.
He's the cool one, he owns the cool stuff.

1275.text:
And also that's his Weeping Angel down there.
Thank you so much for watching this and thank

1277.text:
you for your support during this and I will
be making more videos soon and if there's

1280.text:
a video you'd like me to make… I'm talking
loudly now because of the rain outside, if

1281.text:
there's a video you'd like me to make about
Doctor Who or whatever, then put it in the

1282.text:
comments and I'll try and make it for you.
I'm gonna go now because it's raining really

1283.text:
hard and you won't be able to hear a word
I'm saying. Thank you. I love you loads. Bye!
